state.draftNote:
IDENTIFICATION  
Rashawn Hayes is a 41-year-old man with a history of chronic back pain following a service-related injury in 2003 and a subsequent exacerbation in 2021.  

CHIEF COMPLAINT  
Chronic back pain.  

SUBJECTIVE  
The patient reports a history of back pain that began in 2003 following an IED explosion during military service. He sustained the injury while carrying a fellow service member using a fireman’s carry, which caused him to strain his back. He recalls being evaluated by a PA at the time, who performed an X-ray, prescribed oxycodone, muscle relaxants, and ibuprofen, but no formal documentation or detailed workup was completed. The patient states that he was younger at the time and able to recover more quickly, though the pain persisted intermittently.  

Between 2003 and 2021, the patient describes ongoing back pain, particularly with activities such as standing, sitting, lifting, and transitioning from sitting to standing. He adapted by favoring his left leg and being cautious with lifting techniques. He notes that the pain was manageable but consistently present during this period.  

In 2021, the patient experienced a significant exacerbation of his back pain while lifting beverages at work. He describes the pain as similar to the initial injury, with an acute onset that caused him to drop to the floor. Since then, he reports chronic pain that affects his ability to stand or sit for prolonged periods, lift objects, or perform certain activities of daily living, such as getting on and off the toilet. He continues to favor his left leg to minimize discomfort.  

The patient mentions prior evaluations by a military physician and a possible neurologist or pain specialist, though he is uncertain about the specifics of these encounters. He requests assistance in obtaining any available documentation from these evaluations to support his case.  

The patient also briefly discussed a history of dependency on pain medications, which he attributes to events following his military discharge and divorce. He states that he does not currently have issues with dependency.  

HABITS  
Not discussed.  

PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY  
Not discussed.  

SOCIAL HISTORY  
The patient served in the military and was discharged in 2005. He is currently employed and mentioned starting a new job as a respiratory therapist.  

FAMILY HISTORY  
Not discussed.  

PHYSICAL EXAM  
| Date       | Type   | Value | Unit       |  
|------------|--------|-------|------------|  
| 2025-09-22 | BP     | 122/74 | mmHg       |  
| 2025-09-22 | HR     | 74    | bpm        |  
| 2025-09-22 | Pulse  | 74    | bpm        |  
| 2025-09-22 | RR     | 16    | breaths/min |  
| 2025-09-22 | SpO2   | 96    | %          |  
| 2025-09-22 | Temp   | 97    | F          |  
| 2025-09-22 | Weight | 278.8 | lbs        |  
| 2025-09-22 | BMI    | 35.39 |            |  
| 2024-12-09 | Height | 74.5  | in         |  

No additional physical exam findings were discussed.  

DIAGNOSTICS  
No diagnostics were discussed.  

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  
1. Chronic back pain: Persistent pain following a service-related injury in 2003, with exacerbation in 2021.  
   - Write a letter summarizing the patient’s history and assist in obtaining documentation from prior evaluations.  
   - Provide ibuprofen as requested.  

RETURN TO CLINIC  
Not discussed.  

> This clinical documentation was assisted using an AI scribe. The patient was informed of the presence of a listening and transcribing tool during the visit and given the option to opt out and agreed to proceed. All efforts have been made to ensure the accuracy and confidentiality of the information captured.
